required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Efficacy of Oxymetazoline HCl Cream 1.0% in Patients With Persistent Erythema Associated With Rosacea

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of oxymetazoline hydrochloride (HCl) cream 1.0% (AGN-199201) once daily compared to vehicle for the treatment of persistent moderate to severe facial erythema associated with rosacea.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 2-Grade Improvement (Decrease) From Baseline on Both Clinician Erythema Assessment (CEA) and Subject Self-Assessment for Rosacea Facial Redness (SSA) 5-point Scales
primary_outcome.description: The investigator assessed the participant's overall severity of erythema in the treatment area by using the 5-point CEA scale with photonumeric guide where: 0=clear skin with no signs of erythema (best) to 4=severe erythema; fiery redness (worst). A decrease in the score indicates improvement. The participant assessed their overall severity of rosacea facial redness in the treatment area by using the 5-point SSA scale with photoguide where: 0=no signs of unwanted redness (best) to 4=severe redness (worst). A decrease in the score indicates improvement. The percentage of participants with at least a 2-grade decrease (improvement) on both CEA and SSA from Baseline was evaluated over the 12-hour evaluation period (hours 3, 6, 9, and 12) post-dose on Day 29. Baseline was defined as the measurement at pre-dose on Day 1.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 2-Grade Improvement (Decrease) From Baseline on SSA at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
secondary_outcome.description: The participant assessed their overall severity of rosacea facial redness in the treatment area by using the 5-point SSA scale with photoguide where: 0=no signs of unwanted redness (best) to 4=severe redness (worst). A decrease in the score indicates improvement. The percentage of participants with at least a 2-grade decrease (improvement) on SSA from Baseline was evaluated over the 12-hour evaluation period (hours 3, 6, 9, and 12) post-dose on Day 29.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline on Rosacea Facial Redness as Measured by Digital Imaging Analysis (DIA) at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
secondary_outcome.description: DIA of photographs was used to assess rosacea facial redness and was defined as percentage of facial area occupied by redness. A higher value in the percentage of facial area occupied by facial redness indicated more redness. A negative/ lower number percent change from Baseline indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants Satisfied or Very Satisfied on Item #9 of Satisfaction Assessment for Rosacea Facial Redness (SAT-RFR) at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
secondary_outcome.description: Participants assessed their treatment satisfaction by answering Item #9 of the SAT-RFR: "Right now, how satisfied are you with the effect your study medication had on your facial redness?" using a 5-point scale where 0= very dissatisfied, 1=dissatisfied, 2=neither satisfied or dissatisfied, 3=satisfied, or 4=very satisfied. The percentage of participants who answered Satisfied or Very Satisfied is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline on the Symptom Assessment for Rosacea Facial Redness (SA-RFR) Item # 4 at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
secondary_outcome.description: Participants assessed the burning sensation associated with rosacea facial redness by answering Item #4 of the SA-RFR: "Right now, how much does your face burn because of your facial redness?" using a 5-point scale where 0=less severe to 4=severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 1-Grade Improvement (Decrease) From Baseline on SSA at Hour 1 on Day 1
secondary_outcome.description: The participant assessed their overall severity of rosacea facial redness in the treatment area by using the 5-point SSA scale with photoguide where: 0=no signs of unwanted redness (best) to 4=severe redness (worst). A decrease in the score indicates improvement.

arm_group.description: Oxymetazoline HCL Cream 1.0% applied to the face once daily for 29 days.
Vehicle to Oxymetazoline HCL Cream applied to the face once daily for 29 days.

intervention.description: Oxymetazoline HCL Cream 1.0% (AGN-199201) applied to the face once daily for 29 days.
Vehicle to Oxymetazoline HCL Cream (AGN-199201) applied to the face once daily for 29 days.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
-Moderate to severe persistent facial erythema associated with rosacea.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Greater than 3 inflammatory lesions on the face
- Current treatment with monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors
- Raynaud's syndrome, narrow angle glaucoma, orthostatic hypotension, scleroderma or Sjogren's syndrome.

outcome.description: The investigator assessed the participant’s overall severity of erythema in the treatment area by using the 5-point CEA scale with photonumeric guide where: 0=clear skin with no signs of erythema (best) to 4=severe erythema; fiery redness (worst). A decrease in the score indicates improvement. The participant assessed their overall severity of rosacea facial redness in the treatment area by using the 5-point SSA scale with photoguide where: 0=no signs of unwanted redness (best) to 4=severe redness (worst). Baseline was defined as the measurement at pre-dose on Day 1.
outcome.population: Intent-to-treat (ITT) Population included all randomized participants.

A higher value in the percentage of facial area occupied by facial redness indicated more redness. A negative/ lower number percent change from Baseline indicates improvement.
measure.population: ITT Population included all randomized participants.
measure.units: percent change in area of redness

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants Satisfied or Very Satisfied on Item #9 of Satisfaction Assessment for Rosacea Facial Redness (SAT-RFR) at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
outcome.description: Participants assessed their treatment satisfaction by answering Item #9 of the SAT-RFR: “Right now, how satisfied are you with the effect your study medication had on your facial redness?” using a 5-point scale where 0= very dissatisfied, 1=dissatisfied, 2=neither satisfied or dissatisfied, 3=satisfied, or 4=very satisfied. The percentage of participants who answered Satisfied or Very Satisfied is reported.
outcome.population: Participants from the ITT Population, all randomized participants with data available for analysis.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants Satisfied or Very Satisfied on Item #9 of Satisfaction Assessment for Rosacea Facial Redness (SAT-RFR) at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
measure.description: Participants assessed their treatment satisfaction by answering Item #9 of the SAT-RFR: “Right now, how satisfied are you with the effect your study medication had on your facial redness?” using a 5-point scale where 0= very dissatisfied, 1=dissatisfied, 2=neither satisfied or dissatisfied, 3=satisfied, or 4=very satisfied. measure.population: Participants from the ITT Population, all randomized participants with data available for analysis.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline on the Symptom Assessment for Rosacea Facial Redness (SA-RFR) Item # 4 at Hours 3, 6, 9 and 12 on Day 29
outcome.description: Participants assessed the burning sensation associated with rosacea facial redness by answering Item #4 of the SA-RFR: “Right now, how much does your face burn because of your facial redness?” using a 5-point scale where 0=less severe to 4=severe. A negative change from Baseline indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Participants from the ITT Population, all randomized participants, with data available for analysis at the given time-point. Only participants who had a SA-RFR score of 1-4 at Baseline are included in the Analysis.

reported_events.desc: Safety Population, all participants who applied at least one dose of study medication, was used to determine the number of participants at risk for Serious Adverse Events and Adverse Events.

group.title: Oxymetazoline HCL Cream 1.0%

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: A disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 90 days from the time submitted to the sponsor for review. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
